captions.text: Why shouldn’t we commit suicide?

In his Essay the Myth of Sisyphus, the French-Algerian
philosopher Albert Camus asks us to contemplate

just this sort of question. Deciding whether
or not to commit suicide, Camus thinks, is

‘the only serious philosophical question.’
But why DO people commit suicide?

According to Camus life is absurd, which is
to say, it’s meaningless. Humanity exists

in a constant struggle between expectations
and reality—between our ideals—and how

things really are. And sometimes we realize
this absurdity—all too clearly.

No one particular event triggers this realization.
Any mundane or shocking event may disrupt
our everyday ways of thinking.

The instance where the universe reveals its
indifference to your particular goals—the

tear in the fabric of our constructed lives—this,
for Camus, is the absurd.

To illustrate this point Camus recreates a
famous myth.

Sisyphus was condemned to an eternity of rolling
a rock up a mountain for his belief that he

was more cunning than the gods. As punishment,
the rock would magically fall every time Sisyphus
neared the summit.

Camus claims that like Sisyphus, we’re cut
off from a purpose.

Mario may jump over a thousand fireballs and
collect all of the umbrellas—but none of
that matters if he never saves Pauline.
Our reality is without a defined end goal.
This is the fate that we are condemed to.

There are a few options when confronted with
absurdity. Like Kierkegaard we can interpret

absurdity as part of God’s, larger plan,
but for Camus, thinking like this only distracts
us from the world that we actually live in.

Suicide is NEVER the answer. For killing yourself
only negates the problem rather than solving
it.

So, the answer resides, rather, in chaining
ourselves to absurdity—to making conscious

choices to revel in it. Instead of finding
solace in hope of another world—we ought

to revolt against our condemnation and create
art that reflects our human condition.

Now as bleak as this may seem, Camus, however
proposes an alternate ending to the myth.

As the rock rolls down the mountain, Camus
asks that we imagine Sisyphus happy, in this

act Sisyphus revolts and thereby creates meaning
in his absurd punishment.

After all it’s the act of creating itself
that ought to matter, right?

title: Why Shouldn't We Commit Suicide? (Camus + Donkey Kong) – 8-Bit Philosophy

In this way our expectations are what free us, in contrast to the absurd

comments.text:
We live in a modern society where the media encourages and pushes 
relationships (procreation) with propaganda techniques and euthanasia is 
prohibited completely (except for animals, as humanity values animals much 
more than humans and understands animals psychological issues).  Back to my 
point, this is a entirely wrong approach.  To make things illegal is to say 
"Most people will do this."  Otherwise, if the majority wouldn't do this, 
there would be no reason to prohibit something.  This stands the same with 
everything ranging from vandalism and theft to sabotage and first degree 
murder.  "Things are made illegal to protect society" is the slogan, saying 
that most people left to their own devices are chaotic and nuts enough to 
do it all, with no emotional reaction to boot.  This means that any 
behavior which is a threat to the well-being of modern society and the 
progression of technology and the system, will be managed through the 
system.  Morality isn't always the issue, in fact, many things 
modern-living people are forced into, are by its core, immoral.  How moral 
is mass consumption in truth?  We're forced under a consumer empire that 
maintains the flow of an existent economy.  The same goes with suicide and 
the notion of euthanasia.  If given the right under modern society, for 
people to off themselves, masses of people would choose to do so, 
considering the state of the world.  The end result will be chaos, as when 
the population of a modern society radically drops, law and order no longer 
has nearly as much a stronghold.  In current times of the US, the 
depression rate is incredibly high.  There's a variety of suggestions to 
help the current situation.  Psychiatric drug companies suggest prozac. 
 Holistic healers suggest naturally occurring herbal drugs.  Talk 
therapists suggest one on one discussions to help the depressed feel 
better.  The fighters of the drug war (who often end up losing the fight, 
as it's probably impossible to stop companies and governments) propose the 
medicinal properties of psychedelics (cannabis, mushrooms, LSD, peyote). 
 While it is true that psychedelics have healing properties, this is always 
a transitory effect until people ignore what they learned and go back to 
their old habits that made them depressed in the first place (alcoholism, 
co-dependency, mass media consumption, etc).  Still, the thing is no one 
ever raises the question, "What's causing so many people to be depressed?" 
and address the situation.  You know, cause most people don't really care 
except for caring about money.  The fact of the matter is, the problems get 
worse as people keep procreating.  Overpopulation causes more social 
problems and etc.  If you're not going to kill yourself, at the least, 
avoid the exterior, play your cards right, and most importantly, never get 
in a relationship.  Never procreate (as what relationships are actually 
about).﻿

comments.text:
Ultimately, if a person should commit suicide, is up to the person who is 
or is not going to commit suicide. Nobody exactly understands what a person 
is going through, and why they decided commit suicide. Just as we have the 
right to life, so should would be granted the right to death. Even if they 
commit suicide for the most irrational reason, such as loosing their car 
keys, or a breakup in a relationship, then they should be granted the right 
to end their life, and to have professional assistance with it via the 
medical industry.

Suicide should be just as easy as going to a local clinic or hospital, 
signing a form of consent, paying for the service, the necessary 
precautions, such as taking anti-anxiety, therapy or consultation from a 
priest, therapist, etc., the medication or other stuff to make the suicide 
easier, and then going into a room where the doctor or medical professional 
can induce the suicide to ensure a successful suicide with a high certainty.

As of now if a person wants to commit suicide, they have to do themselves, 
and it leads to many more disasters, then would be if done by a medical 
professional, such as jumping in front of a large vehicle, jumping off a 
high location, medication overdose, etc. If suicide was done in medical 
building, it would be anonymous, unless a person request for people to 
know.﻿

You probably won't believe me, but I have been thinking about killing 
myself and this actually helped.  Because it's logical.  People can say oh 
think about the afterlife, think about the people you're leaving behind, 
and more - but the fact is when you're serious, none of those things matter 
to you anymore.  You're not feeling anything anymore, but the need to end 
the pain, and emotional pleas and "what-if's" aren't always going to help 
someone who's there.  But this actually gave me something to think about. 
 Thanks.﻿

comments.author: diamondmaster99

comments.text:
I think there are two reasons not to commit suicide (continue living), in 
addition to the ones brought up in the video:

*1. Injustice:* The only reason people look for meaning and beauty is 
because we know, on at least a subconscious level, that meaning and beauty 
are sparse if not completely absent from our world. Philosophy and art (and 
thus meaning and beauty) are unnecessary in a perfect world without pain or 
injustice (Aldous Huxley makes good note of that in his famous novel Brave 
New World). We simply wouldn't care either way: life is good. But life 
isn't good, we were thrown into a world of pain and suffering only to be 
rewarded with total annihilation in the form of death. Death is the 
greatest injustice of all, the greatest form of suffering and above all 
there is no meaning to be made from it. It is meaningless suffering. Other 
forms of suffering would be tolerable if it weren't for the fact that all 
of the lessons that we learned from that suffering weren't wiped out after 
we die (because of the sure death of all living things, all of your efforts 
and triumphs over suffering will be lost). The only reason people want to 
commit suicide is to get away from the pain and injustice of life, but as I 
noted, death is the greatest injustice since it is the source of all other 
great injustices (old age, disease, war, etc. are all but symptoms and 
consequences of death existing). So committing suicide really only 
compounds the injustice you've already faced.  

*2. Value of Life:* Value is subjective in that it originates and is only 
made use of in a subjective (i.e. living) creature. Subjectivity is an 
inherent property of being alive, and is only found in living things. 
Value, as with all subjective concepts, in this way belongs to the living, 
and thus all that is valuable, by definition, is that which makes life 
easier or possible. This is because value "owes" itself to life, and the 
concept of subjective ideas like value, justice, and morality evolved/ are 
only there to serve the living. That makes life the most valuable "thing" 
in existence, since life is the benchmark that measures the value of all 
other things and is the origin of value itself. Given that it possesses 
"ultimate" value, life should always be preserved unless a specific life 
does more harm to the prospect of life continuing to exist in the long run 
(the life of a person who seeks to make life more difficult on the large 
scale has lost its value).

(Sorry if the message isn't very clear (especially in the second 
paragraph), I was having trouble finding the words to properly explain what 
I mean.)﻿
comments.author: wii3willRule

comments.text: +waleuska It's obvious you did not read or understand what I was saying.
comments.author: wii3willRule

comments.text:
The way you think of life as if it is a gift. To some people life isn't a 
gift. Death isn't a injustice it is just the way of the world. the only 
thing that is forever is numbers. No matter how long we humans extend our 
lives death will always befall us. This universe will last forever. The 
atoms we are made up of isn't going to last forever either. We all will 
meet death one way or another it is a truth of the universe. It isn't a bad 
thing or a good thing.

Life on the other hand can be bad or good. Life can bring happiness or 
pain. It can bring someone so much pain they would want to end it and they 
should have the right to
comments.author: waleuska

comments.text:
+waleuska "I am sorry but that is a dumb way at looking at life."
Calling the other person's ideas dumb is always a great way to start a 
mature, intelligent discussion.

"For your first point, if someone had an incurable disease and was always 
in pain. Death would be the only way out. A person isn't just going to 
fight it off. There is no cure, you cannot asking that person to not see 
death positive thing."
There's no way out of death for any of us (until some mad genius invents a 
way to live forever). I don't see why you're treating the terminally ill as 
a special group, because the reality is that none of us have any escape 
from death. You may say that death is better than pain, but I think I've 
already addressed that issue in my original post. 
 
"You want to treat death as something bad but it is necessary for life." 
Human death is not necessary at all. Other organisms are all have a special 
role in the environment, we seem to have evolved away from that. 

"On your second point you are right life is a value it is subjective and 
only the person who will that life can but a value to it. If they do not 
think there value is good enough to keep living than they have the right to 
end it. If a person do not think they will have any impact on the world or 
is finish having an impact on the world and is ready to die let them."
Life is the entire reason why values even exist; values are there to serve 
life, so it would make no sense not to value life, if the whole point of 
having values is to preserve life (food is more valuable to a starving 
person than designer clothing, because they would die without food). Values 
are subjective, but they have a purpose and should be used for that 
purpose. Being subjective (in that they only exist in living things), 
values cannot be applied without the subjective context (life itself). 
Anything else is simply illogical.
comments.author: wii3willRule

comments.text:
+wii3willRule I am sorry but that is a dumb way at looking at life. For 
your first point, if someone had an incurable disease and was always in 
pain. Death would be the only way out. A person isn't just going to fight 
it off. There is no cure, you cannot asking that person to not see death 
positive thing. You want to treat death as something bad but it is 
necessary for life. 

On your second point you are right life is a value it is subjective and 
only the person who will that life can but a value to it. If they do not 
think there value is good enough to keep living than they have the right to 
end it. If a person do not think they will have any impact on the world or 
is finish having an impact on the world and is ready to die let them.

comments.text:
Too bad Camus didn't know that much about evolutionary psychology. Life 
isn't absurd. The fact that the universe is void of meaning is entirely 
compatible with our impression and subjective sense for meaning, as it is 
an expression of our emotional nature and our evolutionarily developed 
capacity for emotional appraisal and the projection of value onto the 
world. Hence, we will always, as a defining part of our own nature, have 
emotional appraisal as a source of meaningfulness.﻿

comments.text:
heres a bigger question, if life is absurd, or illogical, why were we given 
logical thought? such as ideals, given logical dreams of a god or a 
paradise and an afterlife where one can live in ultimate happiness and glad 
to be alive, in a illogical world. an absurd world would give us only 
absurd thought, but the logical reasoning in life is to be alive, not to 
die, life was given to live, not to die thus why its called life, unless if 
death is merely another path  that leads to life once again as was why it 
was called life, thus called life, for true death is to never exist, for 
death means for the remains to become nonexistent, not alive, life cannot 
bring non alive outcomes to your existence. the bigger question is. If life 
is merely meant to be suffering but to enjoy suffering, then why do we not 
innately enjoy it, because of nonsense? instead we enjoy joy, thus why its 
called to "enjoy" to be in joy. to enjoy suffering is to be in denial, if 
nothing is logical and reasonable, then there must exist an opposite, a way 
of existence outside of life that is reasonable. the concept of life being 
absurd is a contradiction in its own right, if its absurd, then there is a 
reason as to why its absurd, to be absurd, because your choices and beliefs 
circle around what your biased human mind wants to think because it only 
cares about your belief as to why you feel the way you feel it is absurd, 
your reason as to why its absurd is your belief or choice. my choice, is 
that it has reason, a reasoning to reason, there is no reasoning as to why 
its absurd, as least there shouldnt be. My choice, believes that there is 
god and an afterlife, because I was given thought to think so, there is no 
reason to have no reason, thus, there cannot be no reason and thus nothing 
is done, for all things we do in life, is given for reason, we eat, sleep 
and pray and use the restroom and clothe ourselves for one reason and that 
is to live, we were given life to live, for 0+0 cannot equal 1. C.S Lewis 
once said, 

"supposing there was no intelligence behind the universe, no creative mind. 
In that case nobody designed my brain to be given the purpose of thinking. 
It is merely when the atoms inside my skull happen, for physical or 
chemical reasons, to arrange in such an order that gives me as a by-product 
called thought. How can you trust your own thinking to be true? It is like 
a milk jug hoping that when the milk splashes on the ground, it will shape 
out to be the map of london, but if I cant trust my own thinking, how can I 
find atheistic arguments to be true? Therefore you have no reason to 
believe in anything, unless if I believe in God, I cannot trust thought or 
believe in it, so I can never use thought to disbelieve in God."

thus saying, you can't trust or believe in a man who thinks the world is 
absurd, for he was using thought to say it is absurd. your thought was 
given reason to think that. but if so, how is this world absurd if you were 
given thought to discover that? You cannot use absurdity to say the life is 
absurd, because if your thought is absurd, it is not be trust. therefore, 
the entire argument falls flat on Camus.﻿

comments.text:
So I just need to adapt to my surroundings? If I'm depressed because every 
person I have formed any form of relationship with (family, friends, 
girlfriends) has abandoned me and now ignores me or only acknowledges my 
existence when they need something from me, I just need to adapt! If I have 
no money, no work experience, no job, lack good looks, have no friends, 
have no family that cares (I mean they actually want me out of their lives 
as soon as possible), I just need to create a reason to be happy so that I 
can solve these problems? I'd rather negate these problems, for the 
emotional pain I experience every day is not worth it.
Science proved that Energy is never created or destroyed, only transformed 
into a new form of energy. When a person dies, the energy that runs through 
their body escapes and must be transformed into a new form. It's debatable 
whether the soul is that exact energy. My energy is going to just start 
over as a new life force I hypothesize, so why shouldn't I hit the restart 
button and hope for better conditions?﻿

comments.text:
lol while I have some disagreements with Camus (camooo) - as I don't have 
any problem with afterlife; believing in Heaven and such - I got no problem 
with that - but in principle, yes.  Doing/being is "the thing", not that 
you do it "the best" or "perfectly".   So many great, absurd  but oddly 
helpful cliches like "Journey of a 1000 miles begins with a single step" 
and such or, "It's the journey, not the destination" touch on this notion.  
Seeing it explained with 8-bit Donkey Kong was just perfect.. and I love 
the guy's voice.﻿

comments.text:
OK, I've had a number of people press me for thinking the way I do, yet 
still hold a popular opinion towards suicide...

I just feel that any person should have the "right & entitlement" to *their 
OWN lives*, which is why I hold this position. Yes, holding this position 
means that those I love may take their own lives... but (and while I would 
encourage them not to do it...)... in the end, it's *THEIR* life (and thus, 
*THEIR* choice).﻿

comments.text:
+Allow Assisted Suicide As I clearly stated before, it is not my choise to 
make. I can't stop people from killing themselves.

Yes, generally my desire is to keep people alive as opposed to theirs. The 
reason for this is compassion for them. You see, most people who want to 
commit suicide don't know what they really want. What they really want is 
help, and meaning in life. Personally, I think suicide is always a dumb 
thing to do, but that is not the reason why I oppose it. Only very rarely 
the decision to commit suicide is rational, and the decision is usually 
made by people who could've achieved happiness later in life. Defending 
suicide is defending the act of seizing opportunity from those people to 
make things right. And I want none of their blood on my hands.
comments.author: JooJoona

comments.author: Edwin Contreras

comments.text:
Love this! Mad props for the obscure "Boy and His Blob"-reference @ 2:30


Actually, just realized that the city backdrop is from that game also. It 
also makes a beautiful point about Camus worldview in itself - The boy has 
a blob -it's formless on it's own, just a blob, but the boy has the power 
to create different things out from it, by feeding it candy.

It's like a metaphor of Camus idea of facing the absurdity in itself - if 
existence is merely a meaningless, shapeless blob, why not make it yours by 
molding it as you wish?

That's deep. Definitely subscribed to Wisecrack. Love all of these little 
sub-channels, Thug Notes, Earthling Cinema, etc.﻿
comments.author: hibakusha0

comments.text:
And people bitch about Pascal's Wager... say what you will about valuing a 
finite miserable existence; in the end all you have to offer is more of the 
same. Put on a smile while death impacts your life in various ways; it 
doesn't change the nature of the beast.

When it comes to rejections of Pascal's Wager, all we hear is excuses of 
option anxiety... still rings more solid than, "oh things could get better 
and if they don't, then wear a smile"; tell that to people who's health 
leaves them in perpetual suffering. Possible eternal consequences speak 
volumes more.

Pain sucks and I could easily see good reason in putting someone else out 
of their misery, if such misery is clearly never going to get better, but 
offing yourself is questionable; a lot more questionable if you have 
something to consider that may come after.﻿

comments.text:
As a suicidal person, I've never understood the idea that negating a 
problem isn't an answer. Yes it is. To a suicidal person, living is like 
breathing poison. It hurts, and we want no part of it. So stop breathing 
the poison instead of trying to turn the poison gas into breathable oxygen. 
Negate the problem and it doesn't affect you anymore.﻿

I used to like playing Donkey Kong, but now consider the act absurd, a bit 
like life in late/post modern western culture. The similarities are 
striking for, just like when I used to challenge Donkey Kong, I keep 
getting notifications demanding that I "INSERT COIN", or words to that 
effect. Can't play if you don't pay, and I always end up with empty pockets!
 Suicide would only be viable If our whole species took part in the grand 
event, we need a global Rev Jim Jones. No wait, I forgot, the military 
industrial complex is already leading us down that particular avenue via 
the cycle of resources into waste/pollution through the rationale of 
exponential economic growth and destruction. Our "elected" officials are 
our cult leaders, pretty poor ones though, unlike Jim's followers, we are 
in for a long painful suicide. So everything is ok I suppose! Just don't 
forget to be happy about it, and if you can't be happy, then simply consume 
more! 
 But seriously, throw your television away!﻿

comments.author: Gukkor

comments.text:
Scientifically answered:
Let's say you're unhappy with the state of things in life and the world 
that causes those problems and it's so bad you think killing yourself would 
be better; well it won't be and here the scientific reason why not.

right now we are in complex state of awareness and we have the ability to 
manifest physical intention into reality; we can change the form of life 
and society of the future. If you die then you your particles become parts 
of many other very simple life forms with little to no ability to manifest 
physical intention.

So you would kill yourself only to return as a worm that eats it's own shit 
or a dog who gets beaten, etc.

We at least have the ability to affect change in this form; so suicide is 
counter productive logically.﻿
comments.author: Metaphysical Axiom

comments.text:
+sff This is a perfect example of us needing a translator because of the 
complexity bubble. You will likely continue to misunderstand this complex 
awareness due to your tendencies to over simplify and unrealistic 
perceptional paradigms.

The only thing that will come out of this is "you" getting personally 
offended; "me" getting frustrated and you continuing to delude the field of

You have de-evolved into a common troll, good day sir; post muted; troll

Life forms like you is why I don't bother with most of the world; just 
telling you what other folks in this state are thinking but never say. 
Don't shoot the messenger.
comments.author: Metaphysical Axiom

comments.text:
+Metaphysical Axiom
Utter nonsense. Funny that you were talking about my ego while trying to 
put yourself up on a pedestal saying you're like Mr. Tyson compared to me, 
and so on. I'll just stick to the point: "if the schizophrenic kills 
themselves the particles that make up the schizophrenic will eventually 
become part of a life form that you would like to call a schizophrenic." 
this is true, but again. i'm talking about the duration of the 
consciousness in the unit. i'm not talking about mere individuals, and i'm 
not 'sectioning off' things. obviously the particles that make up one kind 
of thing will eventually reassemble part of a similar thing. but this all 
started because of suicide. because of the pain of a person whose 
consciousness is so afflicted with mental illness that they are willing to 
murder themselves. that pain does in fact end at the end of that brain 
which powers its consciousness. obviously their particles disperse after 
death and then reassemble. but the duration of consciousness plus that pain 
stops once the brain dies. as for 'fighting' i don't care about your 
opinion or getting mental 'wins', i'm more puzzled as to what you mean, or 
what you think that i'm missing. suicide is definitely the answer to stop 
the consciousness's pain. i'm not a fan of suicide, and i think people 
should get treatment. but this is just facts about death ending a specific 
kind of unique conscious pain. obviously the body reassembles into other 
conscious things eventually, and the previous being who committed suicide 
was victim of cause and effect to begin with. everything is 
inter-dependent, etc etc etc. this is not news. the point is, the 
suicidal-level of mental suffering ends for that being when its brain dies. 
that's what this is about. again: after it dies, it will disperse and 
reassemble, all while being part of the inter-dependent causes and effects. 
whatever else — beings or squids, etc...whatever conscious beings that come 
about, that is another journey with consciousness whose relationship with 
the environment can end with the death of its consciousness-giving 
apparatus.
comments.author: sff

comments.text:
+sff​ again a perceptual black hole, you don't see what's right in front of 
you, because of your individualistic hurt butt. 

Now you're more concerned with proving me wrong because of your pierced ego 
then to consider other possibilities, you now want to satisfy your sports 
driven mentality and repair your damaged ego.

And this is exactly what I'm talking about.

A perceptual black hole. You limit yourself. A reminder, I'm speaking to 
you in words you will understand.

Its you who perceive them as you wish, not what I intend them to be. I 
can't control how you perceive intention. 

If you want to get hurt butt and then argue back and forth black and white 
opinions, I could care less about your waste of time bullshit.

You want to perceive reality in a black and white way and then argue with 
about it because of your petty ego, then you're just another example of 
failed perception of reality.

The schizophrenic is created by environment, if the schizophrenic kills 
themselves the particles that make up the schizophrenic will eventually 
become part of a life form that you would like to call a schizophrenic, 
this will happen because lifeforms are produced from the cause and effect 
of environment. The schizophrenic will be born again and we will be part of 
that consciousness. So in that way the schizophrenic escapes nothing.

Meanwhile, if the form of life was complex enough to affect the 
manifestation of reality they could have changed something, perhaps even 
change to themselves once they accept they are ever changing and not an 
individual.

Most psychological issues and problems with society stem from people's fill 
in the blank bullshit and the false perception of reality that is produced 
from it.

Furthermore, you don't realize this but you arguing with me on this subject 
is just like you arguing astrophysics with Neil deGrasse Tyson.

Of course you're pathetically simpleton perception of individualism will 
cause you to receive a statement as arrogant and you are likely to get a 
hutt butt again, even though I'm only proving a point and could give two s*
*** about personal ego. You perceive my words with intention, you don't 
perceive my overall true intention.

This is evidence that the form of life currently expressed is that of a 
simple form, increase complexity of thought. I don't have time to teach 
every puppy to stop pissing on the floor.

Does that insult your petty individualistic ego? I hope so, perhaps you 
will see how easily manipulated you are, with your pathetically simple 
perceptual paradigm black and white individualism.

Have fun filling in the blanks with your opinions and assuming that you're 
the smartest person on the planet, I'm sure that opinion will get you very 
far.

Stay closed minded, don't be open to new possibilities, don't look at 
things like a grey. Good job I knew you can do it.

I really don't have time for this.

Have fun by yourself in a corner arguing with a wall.
comments.author: Metaphysical Axiom

comments.text:
+Metaphysical Axiom your response was condescending despite being wrong: 
'All those pains that trouble you now trouble other life forms also'

again, this is just not true — look around, do you see everyone 'also' 
having debilitating hallucinatory skitzophrenia? your view of the nature of 
pain is simply not sophisticated enough to account for the diversity and 
internal mechanisms of beings.

the fact that cause and effect as well as environment exist in the network 
of phenomena has no bearing on whether or not your own consciousness-caused 
pain ends at death.

the skitzophrenic who is hobbled by hallucinatory hell on earth does in 
fact stop experiencing that hell-on-earth once consciousness is turned off 
(at least so it seems at this point).

your mere assertion that my stance and the stance of David Foster Wallace 
is flawed because it is 'individualist' did nothing to actually justify 
that claim, unless you can explain what exactly in my own words or david's 
is mistaken about death ending consciousness.

i'm understanding that the basic nerve/brain pains continue, so too with 
basic adaptation pressure, habituation, pavlovian-conditioning, and so on. 
but you're utterly missing the point when it comes to conscious beings who 
are experiencing something in their heads that is so bad it makes them want 
to murder themselves. just look at some case studies, man: it's not about 
the world, it's not 'just like' the pain of other things.
comments.author: sff

comments.text:
My point is that, it is without foresight and overly simplistic to hold the 
view that you can escape the pains that trouble you now by killing 
yourself. All those pains that trouble you now trouble other life forms 
also, life forms that your particles will be part of again, there is no 
escaping this fact.

Stop looking at the biota of earth as a bunch of individuals, we are all 
part of the same tree of life, we are all affected by the future state of 
things.

If you dont broaden the scope of your review and followed cause and effect 
to the power of 10 or more, and you will be stuck in a perceptual black 
hole.

The book you're telling me to read, sounds like its writer needs to read my 
book. No its not written yet.

The hellish ride that the mind is aware of in its current state of 
complexity is the product of a chain of complex cause and effect, its 
environmental. If we do not change the environment that causes it we will 
inevitably continue to face the same pain in our next form of life. 
Eventually the worm becomes the human then the human suffers the same fate 
because the environment is causing the same pains. This is because we are 
part of our environment, oneness not individualism.

Everything that you have spoken of, and more than likely everything in the 
book you speak of, was written by an individualist and therefore corrupted 
by fill in the blank opinion and inevitably flawed.

I appreciate the well thought out response, though it still needs some 
thought. That's okay though, it's a process.
comments.author: Metaphysical Axiom

comments.text:
+Metaphysical Axiom
"you would kill yourself only to return as a worm" does not seem well 
founded though. and most suicidal people don't kill themselves because of 
"the state of things in life and the world;" it's the internal hell that's 
key for the suicidal person, not that 'politics is crazy,' 'wall street is 
mean,' 'income inequality continues,' etc. I suggest you read David Foster 
Wallace's piece (RIP) about why suicidal people really kill themselves, 
it's sobering and fascinating.

at death, consciousness's lights are turned off. this is what most evidence 
seems to point out. so the notion that the suicial person's hellish ride 
which occurs during consciousness, does not end at death seems predicated 
on the notion that consciousness's ride as it is constituted doesn't end at 
death. most suicidal people want to put out the fire that is in their head. 
therefore, that kind of death does seem to be the answer for those cases.

is the flea outside my apartment also partly comprised of somebody prior 
who committed suicide? in a vague quantum/particle sense yes. but in any 
relevant sense? the suicidal person who wants to put out their fire, will 
they be a worm who *also feels as if the previous ride hadn't ended*? as if 
their suicidal pains, as they are now, had continued into merely 'worm 
form?' doubtful at this time. and that's the real issue when suicidal 
people worry about rebirth.
comments.author: sff

comments.text:

Filling in the blanks with your opinions equates to a child running with

comments.author: Lord Vivec

comments.text:
Basically, don't waste time thinking how unreasonable life is. It Is What 
It Is, so find meaning in what is. If you really must dwell on the 
contradiction (expectation vs. reality), create something that reflects 
that specific contradiction. The world will come to find meaning in your 
creation, and eventually your existence, rather than you trying to do it 
reverse. It is never the spoon that bends; it's only yourself. This is how 
you overcome the contradiction. ﻿

comments.text:
Why shouldn't you commit suicide? Because you don't get an extra life. 
 Being alive means you have a chance to change your life if you so choose. 
If you're dead you can't change anything. However, what you do with your 
life is up to you.  The meaning of life, personal enjoyment, etc,.. is all 
subjective to each individual's existential experience.﻿

The question is ridiculous. Most of us DON'T commit suicide, simply because 
the circumstances in which we find ourselves select against a genome that

comments.author: HebaruSan

comments.text:
You miss the point of the statement. Camus is making no scientific claims 
about anything - he's simply commenting on which of the three options 
(suicide, transcendence, and acceptance of the absurd) is a more fulfilling 
option. The question of suicide is ridiculous? Tell that to the suicidal 
man.
comments.author: Zachary Leyderman

comments.text:
Please do one on the Philosophy of Language, Mind or Analytic! Wiggenstien, 
Chomsky, or Quine. 

Or, political philosophy: Hobbes, Rawls's, or Singer. ﻿
comments.author: Anthony Cortes

comments.text:
This is a very good explanation of Existentialism in a nutshell. The only 
meaning in life, is the meaning you make for it.﻿
comments.author: Timothy Pulliam

comments.text:
As a living human being I create my meaning of life, as i construct every 
single thing, even the keyboard on my fingertips, right now. Therefore life 
in my eyes isn't without meaning. I don't have the ability to calculate or 
articulate an overall meaning of life in any way. Too many parameters, too 
many constraints, things i won't grep, I can't be Laplaces allknowing 
devil. Another note might be if absurdity is a shortcut for not 
understanding the whole problem, Mr. Camus﻿
comments.author: Sebastian Wilhelm

comments.author: Sefer Özçelik

comments.text: +Sefer Özçelik yeah I love Spinoza, and the fact he sounds very taoism alike
comments.author: Lord Vivec

comments.text:
Hahahah yeah, doesn't leave me too convinced. Committing suicide certainly 
doesn't end the endless cycle of absurdity for everyone else, but it most 
certainly takes you out of the equation.

The question, at least to me, then becomes whether we really wanna commit 
suicide or not. Whether we don't want to revel in the absurd or not. I've 
had a lot of fun with the absurd; this dumb, pointless world has made me 
incredibly happy at times. Of course, (in it's absurd, cyclical pattern), 
this dumb, pointless world has made me sad and depressed and downtrodden. 
But I do know, to a certain extent, that these are feelings, which simply 
aren't permanent. I know that suicide is a rather permanent "solution" to 
these temporary problems of loneliness, sadness, anxiety and the like, but 
it's still a question whether its worth killing myself over. Death is a 
wonderfully simple cureall to all human problems. (This is from a 
standpoint that ignores all the theological hypothetical situations 
following death, but...) You don't go hungry when you're dead. You don't go 
thirsty. You don't miss the company of others. You don't have to worry 
about disease or poverty or anything like that. You don't have to worry at 
all, because you're dead.

So, is it worth it to worry about these things? I guess that would depend 
from person to person. There are certainly aspects of my life that I enjoy. 
While I'm not exactly on the level of "amor fati", I'm trying (amor fati, a 
similarly absurd concept).

I'm reminded of a scene in "Cat's Cradle", where the protagonist and his 
wife come across a mass grave of people who all committed suicide as per 
the instructions of their Holy Man, Bokonon. The apocalypse has come, and 
these people, these miserable people who have never had any beauty in their 
lives, never had any reason to live, who seemingly never enjoyed a moment 
of their poor, hungry, deprived existence (except when listening to the 
words of Bokonon), are all convinced that they should kill themselves.

The protagonist is outraged. He considers Bokonon to be an evil, cynical 
dick with no concern for the lives of others.

The protagonist's wife, on the other hand, says "It's all so simple, that's 
all. It solves so much for so many, so simply." Then she asks the 
protagonist, "Would you wish any of these alive again, if you could?"﻿
comments.author: Sleeves04

comments.text:
Defined Goal?  Defined goal?  What an idiotic assumption.  The ignorance of 
our true identity and purpose languishes under the ignorant assumptions of 
philosophers, trying to think their way around, "Why Are We Here".  With 
little knowledge of our true existence all sorts of assumptions have been 
made and debated, but as humanity begins to wake up, portals of knowledge 
begin to clear up, and thus our philosophy changes to expose that past 
ignorance.

Thus philosophy is no more than the blathering of morons who do not bother 
to explore our greater nature !!!﻿
comments.author: Rumple Stiltskin
